title: Before 1 January 2018, will the Chicago Board Options Exchange's CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) exceed 30?
preds: Since 1990 (when it first came into existence) the VIX has only had 581 trading days with a VIX at 30 or higher. In total there have been 6,970 days since 1990 for the VIX to trade. That is a base rate probability of 8.34% (581/6,970). So, there is an 8.34% probability that the VIX will trade at 30 or higher on a given day. Some more stats, in the last 365 trading days, the VIX has had 0 days at 30 or higher. In the last 730 trading days (2 years), the VIX has had 4 trading days of 30 or higher. Currently the VIX stands at 9.14% at the time of this writing.
I want this to be .5 but the going rate is already close to that.
It's a good thing Bitcoin isn't part of this basket.

"however you measure it, stock market volatility is unusually low. As of September 21, the year-to-date standard deviation of S&P 500 daily returns has been 0.45 percent, the lowest level since 1965 on an annual basis. Intraday volatility is also low. As the chart below indicates, estimates of realized volatility are currently around 6 percent in annualized units, near the minimum of the historical distribution. The chart also reports the Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index (VIX), a market-based measure of implied volatility over a one-month horizon from forward-looking S&P 500 index option prices. Despite a backdrop with high political uncertainty (for example, as measured by Baker, Bloom, and Davis’s economic policy uncertainty index), the VIX is currently around 9-10 percent after hovering near all-time lows for much of 2017.
The index has only breached 30 in the month of December twice in the past 10 years.

Setting my forecast equal to the probability of a 20% decline from the other question.  This probability is almost certainly too high.  If history is an indicator then the right probability is closer to 99.6% against.  That is, even when significant declines happen in the S&P 500, that doesn't always mean that it does so with high volatility slow and steady declines do occur.

Since 1990 (when it first came into existence) the VIX has only had 581 trading days with a VIX at 30 or higher. In total there have been 6,970 days since 1990 for the VIX to trade. That is a base rate probability of 8.34% (581/6,970). So, there is an 8.34% probability that the VIX will trade at 30 or higher on a given day. Some more stats, in the last 365 trading days, the VIX has had 0 days at 30 or higher. In the last 730 trading days (2 years), the VIX has had 4 trading days of 30 or higher. Currently the VIX stands at 9.14% at the time of this writing.

If it didn't happen with North Korea, a missile attack on Syria, Congressional inaction, and the Fed announcing the balance sheet shrinkage, then the list of things that would cause the Vix to spike to above 30 in a few weeks appears to be quite short.

Looking at the VIX data from FRED, covering the period from Jan 1990 to Oct 2017, and taking the price as the random variable. The critical assumption we make is that VIX price follows a Gaussian Law with mean =19.43602, and sd =7.865011, then the probability that ViX is greater than 30 follows. Another critical assumption here is that of Normal behaviour, i.e this scenario is one out of billions and it is only valid if markets are behaving normally, this assumption will break down under excessive market stress.
keep in mind that out of the past 7000 trading days, the VIX was above 30,  580 trading days, which also gives a frequency of approx 8.286%. using a different model that takes into account the behaviour in the tail, and gives  a higher probability of occurring is better than the Gaussian assumption.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Personally, I think this is, in  part, a result of Artificial Intelligence insreacinsgly directing money flows across asset classes. This is more of a hunch than anything I have seen data on, but computers do not react emotionally to headlines like humans do. I am dropping my forecast due to the errosion of time.
I’m adjusting this forecast. I don’t believe, with all that has occurred over the past few months, that we will see event(s) that will move the needle on this to exceed 30.

Base rate calculation: Six out of the last five years. Only 143 days out of 365 until forecast horizon. 1.2*0.3917808219178082 = 0.47. So 47% chance is the base rate.  I'm going with this, with reductions for passage of time until reaching 0% on Dec. 31, presuming the VIX doesn't surpass 30 before then.

What is VIX really? Since it is calculated using out-of-money puts/calls of SPX, it is the collective judgement of investors. The VIX is currently under 16 (the level of VIX when there was political risks such as Charlotteville event), that means investors see that the annualized lost/gain within the next 30 days is about 16% max.
With rising tension in geopolitics, and the financial world retaining low interest rates, near term economic prosperity remains fragile

The VIX hit 17.28 today, which while not the 52-week high, nor is the only time the market has hit 15 in the past few months, still feels like the probability of going higher is up. This is both given the news and reactions from my local population. Adding to this, the VVIX has reached a multi-year high. While not a perfect tool, it feels like it has some predictive powers.
I have so far been using a time series approach as a base for the VIX. Only 12 times since 1991 has the VIX been over 30, without going over 30 in the prior six months, so this is rare event in general. Today I extended this analysis by testing how many times has the VIX reached 30 in the six months after reaching 15, and not exceeding 30 in the six months prior. This is still a less than 1% occurrence. This is not a perfect analysis, but something to hang my hat on.
Raising my forecast to 5%, with regards to the VVIX moving up with the VIX. (I moved my forecast up to 7% yesterday in reaction to the news, but now that I have had more time to think about it, I am going to settle at 5% for now). There are a number of secular  trends weighing on the VIX.

Huge jump in the Vix yesterday, closing at its highest post-US presidential level. This may be nothing or it maybe the start of something much larger, so I am increasing my probability a lot. I will lower it if the VIX subsides.
With today's large movement in the VIX there is certainly an increase in probability, however, there is still a long way to go before the VIX reaches 30.
Even with the North Korean situation I don't believe we'll exceed 30. Unless something further changes here. I'll keep to where I am.
Seeing this in 2018, end of January, start of Febuary and it will be 31.

VIX has only been above 30 for a small number of months in the previous 10 years. Current level is 10.25 despite political volatility in the USA.  Fluctuations in currency values appears to reduce the volatility of share prices because they change the purchasing power available from the sale of a particular share. Fluctuations in currency values seem to reduce the volatility of share prices in USA currency.

I have an interest in financial markets and options markets. In the past 8 years, there have been 4 in which the VIX has gone above  30, however it has ocurred in 2 of the past 5. From 2010-2016, the maximum volatility from August to December has been, 28.92, 48, 21, 21.34, 31.06, 53.29, and 23.01. It should be noted that this we are in an historically low volatility environment, but that there are many reasons in which a short spike in volatility can occur that has little to do with economics. A flash crash or geopolitical conflicts being two reasons. I think that current environment has lower than a baseline risk which I would put somewhere between 30-40%.
Volatility traders haven't been this sure of a stock market shock in almost two years.

Two factors that can bring the VIX above 30:
-The syncronized tightening cycle by the major central banks.
-Geopolitical noises from North Korea, Venezuela, Rusia and Middle East.
In light of a spike in VIX today, reaffirm the probability of VIX going above 30 in the next 5 months is 0.

On a daily basis, a VIX over 30 has occurred 8% of the time, but it there is persistence. If we look at the times with VIX over 30 without an occurrence in the proceeding two months, the rate drops to just 0.25%. However, if we go one step further, over a six month period (with only six months), this base rate is even lower.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Not to say that it is a true 0% chance, but rather that it is closer to 0% than it is to 1%

The CBOE Volatility Index has never closed above 30 in the past five years.  The highest closing price in the past five years was 28 in August of 2015.  During that peak period of time, the Great Recession had officially ended and institutional buyers were regaining confidence in a steady upward trend of the S & P 500.   As far as I can tell, from the financial product's inception in 2004, a daily spike above 30 has never taken place.  Today's closing price is 11.54  with a strong and upwardly trending S & P 500.  I cannot foresee a situation in the next 6 months that would triple the value of VIX shares.

That's quite a bit. Increased computing power, algorithmic trading that is less susceptible to emotion, more warnings by banks and other factors have caused the CBOE VIX to spike less intensely. The near certainty that the White House can't get anything meaningful done is a strong case for an economic status quo domestically (i.e. taxes, healthcare, major legislation). On the other hand, the geopolitical events that could trigger such uncertainty are typically relegated to the executive branch.
historically over lat years this should happen in 14% if instances but I think since we're in  a much calmer world in terms of politics and eas money the chance is smaller in this time period.
Similar question as the -20% downside on the S&P however the chances should be lower as the market could drift lower without a spike in volatility all the way to 30

In the past 10 years, we have three times the VIX gets higher than 30: in 2008-2009, 2010 and 2011. These are times of great uncertainty, financial crisis, Greece default, etc. The VIX also hover around 20. Now, starting below 15, the VIX needs to double, or there must be quite a large movement (30% drop for example) of the stock market. While there are cautious warnings about complacency and over-confidence, the risk of quite large a drop is much less. Worse case, Trump-trade will revert itself to the end of Obama environment (and that assumes the Democrats succeed to totally halt Trump's pro-business pro-market policies). In such scenario, VIX would surpass 20 but would still way below 30.
I will revise the odds when VIX hit 20. As long as VIX stays below 20, the chance for it to go to 30 is nil.

To the surprise of many after Brexit and Trump, things are not causing market disasters or even disorders.  The rest of this year should be calm baring the unforeseen and unpredictable major market shock.  Europe is calming down, China is preoccupied with it domestic market and Trump is unknown enough to trouble makes to keep them cautious at least this first year.
Spikes happen every few years and there now exists a large position that is betting against it happening.
Surprisingly, the economy has been holding steady

my gut says higher, my brain says make a reasonable bet that it will. NOTE that, per this link, he VIX lags the S+P, so if S+P drops, VIX will usually lag a little http://www.cboe.com/products/vix-index-volatility/vix-options-and-futures/vix-index/the-relationship-of-the-spx-and-the-vix-index

The current level of the CBOE's mid-term volatility index, which measures investors' expectations for 6 month volatility, implies that this is quite unlikely. The VXMT is at its lowest level in history:
www.cboe.com/products/vix-index-volatility/volatility-on-stock-indexes/cboe-mid-term-volatility-index-vxmt
Problem is short time frame for this question.

Very similar question to whether the S&P 500 will drop 20% so will start with the same probability and rationale. Last time the VIX hit 30 was in September 2011, so would need something quite major to break the status quo. The FED will start to reduce its balance sheet in the Autumn which could cause some market ripples, but even during the Taper Tantrum of 2013 the VIX did not hit 30. The FED is also more prepared to act decisively than during 2008 should a Lehman like shock hit the markets. The popularity of passive ETF trading seems to have contributed to the smoothing of volatility, although we have not yet seen what effect this phenomenon will have in a downturn.
Mostly baseline rate with some probability added for possible high volatility event.
Very unlikely, given close US equity market tracking of crude oil ~10 years ago, and the S&P 500 ~45 years ago. Expecting a major equities high in early January 2018..

The market appeared to have settled after Trumps election to a very low rate of expected volatility. Given that it is an expectation of the near term volatility, there is no real ability to see a stable six months from this current number. Instead we need to look at what events might create a high degree of price variation with a 30 day time frame. The most likely appears to be "Truvent" (Trump Event). Right now the most likely drivers of uncertainty are investigations that will not be concluded for months yet. Once the conclusion looks to be on the horizon the index will start to raise its head and pay attention. Given the severity of the possible outcomes by comparison to other events that have pushed in the index above 30, the probability of an intra day move above this limit is likely.

It looks like there are three spike clusters above 30 over the last 10 years going back to the financial crisis.
http://www.marketwatch.com/investing/index/vix .
Starting with 3/10 ~30%.

30 on VIX is a great objective test of whether the market is having a mild panic, and for that I would attribute a 33% chance by end year.  However I am also aware that more money is now managed in a passive or quantitative (eg risk targetted) approach, than than through fundamental analysis of earning prospects or valuation.  Put it this way, active investors usually find some money from the back of the sofa following a market sell off, passive investors by definition do not.  Momentum investors such as CTAs, will sell, and push volatility higher in adverse conditions. Risk targeting investors likewise.  In my mind the industry that has sprouted around volatility is similar to structured credit in the mid 2000's, which took a couple of years for inventory to clear.  I suspect volatility might be faster to unwind, but most importantly, any event that pushes it to 20, is likely to see technical pressure blow it to 40.  Which leads me to double the probability to 66%.

While the VIX is highly volatile, and I am predicting in a separate question a big S&P fall this year, I don't see the VIX shooting up to 30 or beyond this year. I just don't see where the extreme volatility comes from.
Barring a trade war, it is currently at an all time low of nine something, so, no.

In about 10% of the tradingdays the VIX was higher than 30 . 1 period of higher than 30 was about 4 - 5 days. So since 1990 the chance vix was over 30 is about 2-4% any coming day. so therefor I expect the vix to be above 30 90%.

Going to stay above consensus on this. VIX 30 implies  about +/- 9% expected 30-day variance for S&P, not out of question. VIX itself is very volatile, 20-30% daily movements are usual. Wouldn't be surprised if we will get some bumpy ride into the end of 2017. Hope not.

It is more than 0%. It has been above 30 several times in the past few years. There are only 5+ months left in the year, however, and VIX is lower than it's been in a while. I still see it as possible.

I don't believe we'll see the volatile market as we saw in 2016 (http://money.cnn.com/2016/01/29/investing/dow-january-2016-worst-month/index.html) Certainly not this year unless some international catastrophe would strike, though 2018 may be a different year going into it's the 3rd quarter.  And yes, there is so much that can happen - like North Korea testing another bomb, terrorist attack on our shores, or financial collapse of a major bank. But, some of that may not affect the market that badly.

Today VIX IS 10.42.  It is highly unlikely, despite tepid growth in the domestic economy, that we will see such volatility in markets;  the level of volatility in the IFP suggest movement toward a major financial crisis.   Given Trump's exogenous effects on markets, it remains unlikely to move to 30 or above.
If this includes hitting 30 but not necessarily closing above 30 then there is a reasonable chance. Unforeseen world events could cause a brief spike.
Things have to get pretty crazy for this to happen.  So don't rule it out.
